It isn't that it is a stupid question.  The thing is to ask questions
smart=
ly.  One of the best things to do before asking the question is
read the do=
cumentation, or do some research.  Since your questions are
such simple thi=
ngs, I don't really mind offering a "free" answer.  If
were something that =
I thought you should do some research, I would have
said so.

-jason

>>-----Original Message-----
>>From: Rogers, Jason [mailto:jrogers@=
gltg.com]
>>Sent: Thursday, November 29, 2001 6:48 AM
>>To: junit@yahoogrou=
ps.com
>>Subject: RE: [junit] Testing OS specific end-of-lines in the stand=
ard
>>out of a program
>>
>>
>>Instead of using literals in the program (\n=
 \r), use the
>>System.getProperty("line.separator") and test against that =
if you need
>>to test it.  Using this and others in the code (i.e.
>>getPro=
perty("file.separator") or File.SEPARATOR, etc.) will greatly
>>reduce the =
need to "port" to other OS's.
>>
>>-jason
>>

>>Now that the good folks of this list have assis=
ted me in obtaining the
>>standard out of the java object that I was testin=
g, I have one further
>>question.
>>
>>What is the prevailing best practice=
 for testing the output 
>when it has
>>different end-of-line markers from =
different operating systems? My
>>lovely new tests are failing on Microsoft=
 Windows!
>>
>>I use Linux primarily but also have to deliver software and =
their unit
>>tests to people using Microsoft Windows and let's not forget M=
ac OSX.
>>
>>Thank you in advance.
